thread.title: 107 years later, these young, powerful Cubs are due
thread.title_full: 107 years later, these young, powerful Cubs are due | New York Post

author: Kevin Kernan
title: 107 years later, these young, powerful Cubs are due
text:
CHICAGO — This is a baseball rebirth.
The Cubs are back and are only one win away from advancing to the NLCS. This was a Wrigley Field party with all the kids invited — especially slugger Jorge Soler, who has yet to make an out this postseason.
The young hitters are paying off earlier than expected.
A monster in the Midway came alive Monday night with the 8-6 win over the creaking Cardinals at windy Wrigley Field to give the Cubs a 2-1 lead in the NLDS.
The Cubs smashed a postseason-record six home runs as batters one through six went deep. Yes, the wind was blowing out, but these were all serious blasts.
It was the running of the bulls after each home run in the Cubs dugout, their home-run ritual.
This marked the Cubs first postseason win at Wrigley since 2003 — pre-Bartman.
So, Anthony Rizzo, one of the six Cubs to club home runs, what was the atmosphere like on this windy and wild Wrigley night?
“Every time I screamed, personally, I thought I was going to faint,’’ the big first baseman said.
Another win Tuesday night and the Cubs will have captured their first-ever postseason series at Wrigley.
Rookies Soler, Kyle Schwarber and Kris Bryant homered as well as Rizzo and young second baseman Starlin Castro, as the Cubbies manhandled Michael Wacha, the bullpen and the 100-win Cardinals. Veteran Dexter Fowler added the sixth home run in the eighth.
“The wind was blowing out before the game but I wasn’t thinking about that number,’’ Bryant said of the six-pack of home runs.
When Soler homered in the sixth on the first pitch by reliever Adam Wainwright, it marked the fourth hit of his postseason and second home run. He has reached safely in all nine playoff plate appearances, the first time that has ever happened.
“I’m locked in right now,’’ the massive Soler said through an interpreter. “I have tremendous confidence.’’
Noted Bryant, “That home run he hit was unbelievable. It was a two-iron.’’
Bryant and Rizzo were a combined 0-for-21 in the postseason when the game began.
The baseball world knew the Cubs’ young players were coming, but they have arrived faster than anyone expected, making them such a scary proposition now and into the future.
Soler is 23. Bryant is the same age. Schwarber is 22. Castro is 25 and Rizzo is 26. Shortstop Addison Russell, who tripled in the fourth, is 21. On the play he injured a hamstring and was replaced by Javier Baez, who is 22.
Schwarber was the MVP of the Futures Game at the All-Star Game in Cincinnati this July.
This was another Futures Game with all this young talent and it made up for a night when Jake Arrieta was finally human.
“We told Jake we had his back tonight,’’ Castro said.
A win Tuesday night and the Cubs have a chance to get to the World Series and win their first World Series since 1908.
This postseason marks a rebirth for both the Cubs and Mets. This is the first postseason for the Mets since 2006 and the first for the Cubs since 2008. In both 2007 and 2008, while the Mets collapsed, the Cubs were soon getting bounced in the NLDS with three straight losses each year.
Each franchise has two World Series victories and is craving for success. The Cubs two World Series wins came in 1908 and 1907. Wrigley wasn’t built until 1914.
They are due.
You can say the same thing for the Mets and their World Series victory years of 1986 and ’69.
An NLCS showdown will be something special.
If the two teams get there, the Mets may need a little help from a black cat back like the old Miracle Mets days to get past these mighty young Cubs.
Noted Rizzo, “That was a fun game in general, the best one I’ve ever been a part of.’’
Hey, the fun is just beginning around Wrigley.
